The shower curtain did not cover the whole width of the shower so the floor was wet if you weren't careful.Overall, we were VERY happy with this hotel.

hotel_name: DoubleTree by Hilton Alana - Waikiki Beach
review_body: When I read the reviews for this hotel, I was a bit iffy about it, but once we arrived, we were so surprised!! It was a great hotel. It's situated at the perfect location. It's right at the corner on Ala Moana St. (street takes you straight to the airport or car rentals only a 20 min. drive) and Kalahua (takes you straight to the beaches and shopping). Since it's basically the last hotel on the strip of Ala Moana, you don't feel crowded in by the other hotels. If you don't like to walk or stroll around to take everything in, you can take the FREE trolley to the beaches. My husband and I preferred to either walk or drive (FREE PARKING) and park our car at the end of the Waikiki beach (Honolulu Zoo). I loved that we had valet parking ($22 p/day). We didn't have to worry about parking lots being closed or someone breaking into the car. Valet is 24/7. The room was super clean and we had room service cleaning everyday with clean towels and they restocked our coffee and Neutrogena shampoos. Blow dryer, iron and ironing board are provided in the room and you can watch some free channels or order movies and pizza with beer for $12 bucks!! The pool was nice and warm and NEVER crowded. Only a few folks at a time would take a swim, I guess everyone perferred to walk to the beaches. Although they serve dinner and breakfast at the hotel's restaurant, we preferred to eat at the 24 hr coffee place down the block. It's open daily and they serve, breakfast, lunch and dinner. We went there once and the line wasn't long, but if you go and there is a line, it's worth the wait. Other nights, we took a few steps to the Cheeseburger Waikiki restaurant or crossed the street to eat at Tony Roma's or just walked over to Señor Frog's and Altlantis Seafood. My favorite spot was at the Shore Bird Grill about a two blocks down from our hotel and right next to Fort de Russy. We grilled our own shrimp and steak and the ocean view was beautiful. From there, we took a stroll on the beach and walked into any bar hoping from the beach. It was great. BEST OF ALL, since we booked our hotel through their website, we were able to get it at a lower price PLUS since we have AAA, they offered another discount. All in all, we loved the Double Tree Alana Waikiki Hotel. It was wonderful. I highly recommend it and please, if you can walk, do it and enjoy it. Expect for it to be hot, but there is plenty of shade everywhere and you can always walk into any store (ABC especially) and cool off. It's Waikiki, what else do you expect?

hotel_name: DoubleTree by Hilton Alana - Waikiki Beach
review_body: The rate is fair. The beach and everything is within a walkable distance. Valet parking only but inexpensive parking is just nearby. Warm cookie and Kona coffee is served at check-in and refreshed everyday respectively. Bathroom is small and the shower water soaked the floor after use. The washroom consumables are in good quality and the maid served us well. The room is far from spacious especially the bathroom but is still recommend.

hotel_name: DoubleTree by Hilton Alana - Waikiki Beach
review_body: I have booked this hotel, since it was reasonable and one of the Hilton Family. Turned out to be a terrible hotel. You have to take a cab to go to the middle of Waikiki ( unless you want to walk for 30 min. in hot and humid), and front desk is never available. And put you on hold for 5 min. We were going to make a reservation for dinner and called concierge at 5:00pm, however she was already gone for the day. Since we forgot to tip the maid, we were accused that we stole stuff from the room and they charged to my credit card. Only one elevator was working and waited for 10 min. to get on the elevator. Bathroom was very small and can't even turn around in the shower. Parking was Valet only, and $19 a day. The pool was gross. It is a totally business hotel on business with limited budget, not for vacation for sure. Terrible service and terrible management. Can't believe you use Hilton name for it.

hotel_name: DoubleTree by Hilton Alana - Waikiki Beach
review_body: The Double Tree is a smaller hotel now part of the Hilton Family of hotels. this property is being updated but there are some noticable shortcomings. The bathrooms are very small. they offer a 1/4 tub that you can stand in for a shower, not a full size bath tub. When inquired about moving to another room with a full tub I was told the price would double. If you require a full bath or simply need space to shower it will be a problem at this hotel. They have installed a ledge for towels running along the wall above the toilet and sink rendering the sink almost unusable. You cannot wash your face without banging your forehead on the ledge. Also we learned about "code" 28. it stands for a backed up toilet which happened to us twice during our stay. the maintenance man told us the plumbing in the hotel is inadequate. We noticed that our deck had something spilled on it from an upper floor. we asked for it to be cleaned and wasn't by the time we checked out. The hotel has been upgraded in the lobby and dinning areas which are nice. the front desk staff was helpful. You will get approached about Hilton timeshares while you are there. This hotel is on a busy street.

hotel_name: DoubleTree by Hilton Alana - Waikiki Beach
review_body: Upon reading another review on staying in the Penthouse, I decided to book it. As it turns out, the hotel only has two Penthouse suites located on the top floor (19th). It is situated at the end of one side of the building and right outside of the doors, there is your elevators and ice machines (we couldn’t hear the elevators as 1: there wasn't really anyone coming and going on that floor or 2: they insulated the sound very well). As soon as you open the door, you have the bathroom on one side. The bathroom is a decent size, but it was surprisingly small considering it was a suite. (See pictures; the pictures make it look better than it really was). Other reviewers have mentioned that they have spotted molds in the bathroom. I myself did see a few speckles around the toilet (however, armed with a packet of antibacterial wipes I was more than ready to combat them). The bathtub is what they called the “furo” tub so it was very tall. Therefore, one should be extra careful when getting out or you will get hit! There was a shower head and handheld spray situated oddly in the middle of the wall as well. The only discrepancy that really bothered me was the shelf above the sink. While it was handy to stash your own amenities, it covered the faucet and there was barely a 10” gap opening between that and the sink. So bring a cup to brush your teeth or use the one from the hotel. Otherwise you will have a very difficult time. Strangely, the bathroom is shut by a very dated sliding door. Next to the bathroom, you have a vanity area with several quartzs. Basically it was just a marble slab with a bench and two sconces positioned on top of the glass on one side with recessed lighting above.Okay, so here's a quick rundown of the room:The positives:- Free cookie at Check-in (not the greatest cookie, but it was warm)- All the employees we’ve encountered were super friendly- Tons of storage space if you are planning to bring plenty of clothes. There is a big walk in closet with ironing board & iron with wooden hangers (as well as a flashlight). There is also a pullout for laptop on the night stands as well as many drawers.- Very soft and comfortable bed, as they claimed that it was custom made for them by Serta. However, if you are over 6ft tall you might want to sleep diagonally as the bed is short in length.- Two balconies (one large, one small)- View of the Fort DeRussy Park and ocean afar is quite beautiful (see photos) but it’s kind of blocked by many other hotels close by.- Unique art pieces in the room and bathroom (quartz mostly, but feels very dated) - Free HBO - Coffee pot with two packages of free coffee (caffeinated and non caffeinated) and condiments packs- Neutrogena soaps, shampoo, conditioner, lotion- Hair blow dryer in bathroom, but it seemed like it wasn’t used in ages as there was a lot of dust stuck in-between the flip buttons- Mini refrigerator that’s empty for you to stock up on snacks! The negatives:- Not close to the beach. It is situated at the beginning of Waikiki so you can avoid crowds but it also means long walks. (Set aside at least 20-30 mins if you want to get to get to the end of Waikiki; i.e. the Zoo) - Lobby for check-in is actually on the second floor, which means you have to lug your luggage up the elevator or escalator. But before you can do that, you need to go up several steps of stairs first. - Very tiny elevators. One will possibly fit at most three people with three suit cases.- Local calls are not free, I think they were $1.00 per use plus surcharge for each minute - Newspaper (USA today and The Honolulu Advertiser) delivered to your room is not free. The price is added to the price you are paying for the room, but they say it can be refunded if you tell them ahead of time that you don’t want it.- Rusted bathroom door- Parking: there is only valet parking which is currently at $19 a night not including tips- Glass sliding doors to go out to the balconies/ deck are difficult to open. It needs cleaning/ oiling.- The small balcony looked right into the adjoining suite's balcony and the building across. The chairs were also starting to rust.- No complimentary slippers or robe - Room is small for a “suite”- Buildings all around the hotel block majority of your view- There is only one light in the bathroom and it is right above the sink; making the room seem dimmed- Large red spots on the green carpet by the sitting area- Outdoor deck is connected to the other room’s deck and there is a locked glass door by the elevators adjoining them (where everyone can just look in).- Room was not insulated well from outside noises (we heard a car start its engine from the parking lot below). Overall, the deck is the only thing that made getting the penthouse seems worth it (as the inside of the room is a bit worn out). From the hotel pictures and the fire exit plans in the room, the 19th floor suites seems like they are all of equal size in dimensions. If you don't need the deck, then you are probably better off getting a regular suite. Even though the deck is connected to the deck of the other suite, it is still a nice place to relax and bask in the sun. Just don’t expect total privacy as the hotel is surrounded by so many other buildings towering over it on both sides.

hotel_name: DoubleTree by Hilton Alana - Waikiki Beach
review_body: I have stayed at the Doubletree approximately 10 times over the past five years, and generally alternate between the Doubletree and Ilikai. I am a frequent business traveler, so my priorities are a lot different than most visitors to Honolulu. I like to stay at the Doubletree for the following reasons: 1. good location at western margin of Waikiki (my office is near the airport), 2. hotel is good value, 3. rooms clean and beds comfortable, 4. in spite of being located on Ala Moana Blvd., hotel is very quiet because windows are nicely soundproofed, 5. quick and easy to get in and out of hotel, 6. good inexpensive restaurants in the vicinity where the locals eat (try the Wailana Coffee House or Eggs n Things for breakfast), 7. staff friendly and helpful, 8. hot gooey chocolate chip cookie upon check-in.I don't recommend the hotel for honeymooners or those that want the hotel itself to be the fun experience. For that, better to stay at the Hilton Hawaiian Village, Marriott, Sheraton or one of the other big hotels with shops, parrots and all the rest. Also, hotel not recommended for those that want to be on the beach (10 minute walk). If you are looking for value and efficiency over luxury, and don't need your hotel stay to form memories that last a lifetime, try the Doubletree.

hotel_name: DoubleTree by Hilton Alana - Waikiki Beach
review_body: After reading some of the reviews of the Alana, I was a bit concerned that we might not be happy with it. I agree with another review that with a family of 5, there are limited choices. We have been very happy with the Alana. I sit here in the suite typing this review with our incredible Hawaiian trip almost finished. The staff here has been wonderful. We had been told before leaving Iowa that we could use the Hilton Hawaiian Village facilites since the Alana is a Hilton property, but the front desk said that was incorrect-you had to be a Hilton club member to do this. Well, I can still say, my family really enjoyed the HHV's pool. The one thing that did bother me a bit was my thinking that the USA Today and Honolulu papers at the door every morning were complimentary-however, the small print shows that you are charged for them unless you tell them not to. Not a deal breaker. It's just a short walk from the Alana to Waikiki. The valet parking is about $20 a night if you decide to rent a car which we did for a couple of days. The pool at the Alana is not bad, small and heated and cozy. But everyone has been so nice here and helpful. Everything you need is within easy walking distance. We are very happy that we are staying at the Alana and would recommend it to anyone. The rooms are clean and the cleaning staff is great too. But you will find yourself not staying in your room for much of your trip I hope. Finally, it is a bit noisy at night on the street, but hey, if you want total quiet, dont stay at a hotel on Ala Moana and close your window. All in all, we love our stay and think you will too. As far as Hawaii goes, it's very affordable.

hotel_name: DoubleTree by Hilton Alana - Waikiki Beach
review_body: As Hilton Honors member I booked 2 rooms (ocean view) through the website for $179 pp/nt. I a travel agent friend recommended this property but it is definitely sub-par! I have stayed at many Hilton properties and never had a room that was this disappointing.We checked in late on Friday night and when I got to my 16th floor room it smelled horribly like mold/mildew. Although it is a smoking floor, the smell was not smoke. It was like a dirty, moldy bathroom. I called the desk and was offered to move to a room on the 6th floor (at midnight after a 14 hour flight) but they warned me there was some sort of teenager group staying there and it might be noisy! No thanks! Next they brought up a dehumidifier that looked like it was made in the 1960's and hadn't been used since then. When the woman turned it on it blew out big dust bunnies all over the room! I barely slept that night and had to keep the balcony doors open. The next morning I inquired about being moved to a comparable room and was told they were all sold out. Maintenance came and changed the filters in the vents and the AC but it still smelled. I woke up sick 4 days in a row and kept the balcony doors open almost all day and night. (Beware if the little birds who will fly in if given a chance) My colleague informed me that her room did not smell that bad other than the bathroom.Other issues: The noise was horrible, every time someone opened their balcony doors I was woken up. The bath tub was about 3 feet long and 3 feet deep. I guess "soaking tub' means for soaking legs& feet? i am 5'9" and could not ever fit in this tub! The shower curtain did not cover the length or width and the floor got soaked every time I showered. The "fitness center" consists of 2 treadmills and a bicycle outside next to the pool. After almost $4000 for 2 rooms/ 9 nights they then told me at checkout in the morning that there was no place to take a shower before our 9 pm flight. My friends who stayed at the Hilton were allowed to use a hospitality suite after checking out in the morning.I will say the concierge and the server we had at the restaurant, Tina, were some of the nicest people I met on O'ahu. Also my room was cleaned everyday and the housekeeping staff were very friendly and courteous.After walking around a lot I would strongly recommend staying further down Kalakaua Ave. at the Sheraton, an Outrigger or at the Hilton Village even if it costs a bit more.

hotel_name: DoubleTree by Hilton Alana - Waikiki Beach
review_body: It's hard to get a room for a family of 5, so the suites at the Doubletree made the most sense economically. The layout of the suites are really strange, but there was a lot of room to move around. We stayed on the 10th floor, overlooking the pool on our first weekend, and on the 6th floor, same location on our last weekend. Both rooms were right next to the elevators and behind the ice macine, but the noise did not bother us. The view was of an ugly apartment building, but we didn't stay there for the view. The rooms were quite clean, but the shower curtain in the room on the 6th floor could not be closed and water leaked onto the floor. After 3 showers it was quite wet in the bathroom. We ate breakfast at the Wailana restaurant 1/2 block away. Good food, reasonable prices. The breakfast buffet at the hotel was $17 each, while the bill at the Wailana came to about $50 for all 5 of us.Very fast check in, warm cookies, nice beds. I'd stay there again except that I didn't like Honolulu in general and would find a place to stay on the North Shore.

hotel_name: DoubleTree by Hilton Alana - Waikiki Beach
review_body: My wife and I wanted to go to hawaii for a very long time, but did not know where exactly where we wanted to stay. The doubletree was by far the best place to stay. The room we were in was 1912 a penthouse suite on the 19th floor. It had view of the ocean and a view of waikiki. Everything was in walking distance and was no problem to reach. Staff was friendly and very professional. Breakfast was top notch from omelets to waffels it was excellent. Activities were abound from the Paradise cove luau to horseback riding on the Kualoa Ranch the doubletree made this vacation one to remember. The only downside was the lack of a microwave oven in the room, other than that perfect. Stayed at the doubletree June11th to June17th.

hotel_name: DoubleTree by Hilton Alana - Waikiki Beach
review_body: We spent three nights at the Doubletree Alana in April, and due to a friend who works for The Hilton Family, we were able to get a special Friends & Family rate of $99 a night. As with a lot of hotels in Waikiki, there is only valet parking available, which is $19 a day. It's about a 5 to 10 minute walk to Waikiki Beach via the Hilton Hawaiian Village, which wasn't really an issue for us because that was not the reason for our trip to Honolulu. The front desk staff were quite nice, and we were given a room that is the closest to having an ocean view. The room (1219) its self was adequate, nothing spectacular and one of the smallest rooms on the floor, with a lanai, comfortable king bed, and desk, but oddly no other table or chairs. The room was behind the elevator shaft which was quite audible, but the real problem was the bathroom. On the hotel's website, and in guidebook reviews, they make a strong note of the Furo style soaking tubs which we were looking forward to. In our room at least, it was a square with no light where there wasn't much room to stand in, much less soak. Perhaps they confused "soaking" with deep, for it was extremely difficult to get in and out of, and we're limber 20-somethings. The shower curtain was completely useless.....it wasn't wide enough to cover both ends of the tub, so water would seep out everywhere onto the floor. The taps for the sink were located under a shelf that ran the length of the wall and were very difficult to turn on and off. The spout was under the shelf as well which made it challenging for face washing, teeth brushing, etc. There was also a clear acrylic shelf hung low that was nearly invisible, so invisible that my fiancé cut his head on it.We didn't eat at the hotel, rather we walked to Ala Moana Center's food court or further into Waikiki. We didn't use the pool or fitness center either, but we did use the business center a few times for internet access, which costs $1 for 5 minutes.We were told that the most discounted general rate (the Friends & Family rate can only be booked by a Hilton Family employee) for the time we were there was $169. If you come to Honolulu specifically for Waikiki, stay elsewhere. If you do stay at the Doubletree Alana, do it only because you know someone who works for the Hilton Family....$99 is worth it, $169 is definitely not.

hotel_name: DoubleTree by Hilton Alana - Waikiki Beach
review_body: My fiance and I stayed at this hotel the first weekend of April. It exceeded my expectations. I though this would just be like any other average hotel but is not as bad as it seems. The room was large and the bed was very comfortable. It is within walking distance to the beach, major bus stops, shops and malls. It is one block from the Hilton Village Hotel. You can use their facilities at no cost and walk to the beach from there. The Doubletree offers a nice buffet breakfast and not as expensive as other hotels. It offers all kinds of breads, cereals, fruits, omelettes and a variety of hot items. Unfortunately, we were not able to use the pool since it was being renovated. But that's ok since the beach is not far. We will definitely stay at this hotel again.

hotel_name: DoubleTree by Hilton Alana - Waikiki Beach
review_body: My boyfriend and I stayed here on his business trip. The location was surprisingly close to the beach, about a 5 minute walk! It is located on the north section of Waikiki Beach one block from the Hilton Hawaiian Village. The main stretch of shopping is also about a 5 minute walk away. You can easily walk to Ala Moana Park/beach if you prefer even less tourists.The rooms were modern and clean. The pool was basic and nice on the 2nd level. The internet service wasn't reliable though. The bar/restaurant wasn't exactly "hoppin" but the employees were all friendly. I'd skip having a drink or food there. This hotel seems to be more business oriented than touristy which was perfect for our purposes. It is far enough away from the crowded section of waikiki.There is a cheap diner between the hotel and the hilton with a delicious breakfast. We also ate at an upscale thai restaurant that had wonderful food on the corner! All in all good value for the price ($170/night when we stayed there).

hotel_name: DoubleTree by Hilton Alana - Waikiki Beach
review_body: Very nice hotel with good service. The location was just one block away from the Hawaiian Hilton Village, which was an easy walk to the beach. We would walk there and down the beach each morning to east breakfast at a different hotel. Cheeseburger and Paradise was just next door and Eggs and Things and Keos just a short walk from the Hotel. Again, good location for cabs and the bus.

hotel_name: DoubleTree by Hilton Alana - Waikiki Beach
review_body: After bumping our initial $240 a night room upto $999 without telling us.... they fixed it up and upgraded us for the inconvience. The room was nice and a good size but it certainly was not worth the money we paid. I have stayed in better hotels in Waikiki and paid less than half the price I paid here. We were in Hawaii during the Honolulu Marathon so we had to book this place cause everywhere was sold out. The pool area was nice. The windows and sliding doors in the room would make that annoying wind howling sound when they were closed even though it wasnt windy outside.

hotel_name: DoubleTree by Hilton Alana - Waikiki Beach
review_body: the hotel was ok....but not good enough for a relaxing and luxurious vacation, so if you have some money, get a better place.

hotel_name: DoubleTree by Hilton Alana - Waikiki Beach
review_body: We were referred to this hotel when the other place we wanted to stay was sold out. \ I was a little nervous after reading the other reviews but must admit that our experience was wonderful. The customer service was excellent, our room was clean and spacious (and there was absolutely no mold in the bathroom). The room had a balcony big enough for two chairs, and a small refrigerator. The room was quiet. The food at the hotel was a little overpriced (but c'mon, when is hotel food not overpriced?). There are a couple of close options for dining. The hotel is just a few blocks from beach access and high-end shopping. I would definitely stay at this hotel again (but next time, I would probably pay the extra and stay directly on the beach).

hotel_name: DoubleTree by Hilton Alana - Waikiki Beach
review_body: I was SO SCARED that my company had put me in this hotel after I read some of the reviews posted here! HOWEVER, I am completely comfortable here. (Literally - I'm in the restaurant right now using the free wireless internet!)The room is just fine. My room does not reek of mold (as I was afraid of!) It was a touch musty, but I opened the door to the balcony and it aired out quickly. It is pretty clean - bathroom corners could use a good scrub, but I'm not frightened by any means. The shower is strange - to agree with a prior review. It has a pretty high "wall" around it - at least 24" (It is above my knees) with a square corner, so slipping would be a disaster! The towels are sort of old & not very soft, but they are clean.Overall, I would stay here again. The parking is expensive, but somehow our travel agent got the $14/day fee waived. Valet is kind of a pain - and if there are more than 3 cars in line, you will wait in the street until they get them moving. But, it is nice not to have to search for a parking spot and haul your bags a mile.My complaint would be the restaurant. The breakfast is pricey (parking they would waive, but not breakfast, and I am a Hilton Gold member). They only have one waiter (as far as I can tell.) You will wait for him to find you and seat you, and then you will wait again for him to bring a menu (you see where I'm going with this.) Eating here is not quick, even with a breakfast buffet. Well, eating is quick, but sitting, and waiting for your check is slow.

hotel_name: DoubleTree by Hilton Alana - Waikiki Beach
review_body: We flew into and out of Oahu for our July 2006 trip. But the 7 days in between were spent in Maui. So we stayed here July 3rd and then again on the night of the 10th.My husband is a Diamond Hilton Honors member. We booked this hotel with Hilton Points and we thought we would be in a “city view” room . Upon check in, we were upgraded to the Penthouse, room 1911. It was absolutely amazing!! Full 180 degree views of the ocean and the city. We even had a great view of Diamond Head. The room was huge with 2 balconies. One was your average hotel size…..the other was larger than my living room at home. It was beautiful with cedar floors, wood patio furniture and a cloth covered roof. The room was very large and spacious as well. There was an area with 2 couches and tables and TV. There was also a bar area. The 2 balconies with sliding glass doors made it feel so open. And waking up in the morning with these amazing views all around you was priceless.The free breakfast bar was good and the $5 upgrade to the full buffet was really great!Our second night there at the end of our trip....the hotel was booked solid. So this time we were only upgraded to the 18th floor. The room was clean and I did not see any mold that others have mentioned. The shower was oddly small, but clean. A nice room, but clearly nothing like our experience in the penthouse.We asked about late check out since our flight did not leave until late the next day. Even with the hotel completely booked, they accomodated us. They called at 7:00 am and told us we could check out at 3pm. Then they held our bags for another couple hours while we had drinks at Cheeseburger in Paradise down the street. In short, we were very pleased with this hotel. Though we did stay here for free. If you can get the penthouse...do! We felt like rockstars with the rooftop gigantic balcony!!

hotel_name: DoubleTree by Hilton Alana - Waikiki Beach
review_body: Don't stay here no matter how good of a deal you get. I stayed at this hotel for one night and that was enough. If I wouldn't have been able to find a different hotel in Waikiki I would have considered flying home. Good Things:1. You get a cookie when you check in.Bad Things:1. MOLD. Our room was covered in mold and mildew, you could see it growing under the wallpaper. It wasn’t so bad to see it, but to smell it is a different story. It was so gross. We arrived there at Midnight so we didn’t have any other choice but to spend the night. The smell was so strong that I had to tie a shirt around my head to sleep. 2. Room was dirty….shower shoes required dirty.3. Far from the beach and from the main strip.

hotel_name: DoubleTree by Hilton Alana - Waikiki Beach
review_body: The room was nice but their idea of an ocean view room for $200+ is a joke, we could hardly even see the ocean from our room. All we could see were a bunch of buildings & off to the corner a bit of the ocean. The cookies that were promised at check in were not hot & they contain nuts, what about those who are allergic to nuts?! We requested a late check out & were told we would be notified by 7am whether or not this was possible and no one bothered to contact us. Staff seemed like they didn't care about providing good service.

hotel_name: DoubleTree by Hilton Alana - Waikiki Beach
review_body: After "winning" a bid on Priceline for $95 per night, I was advised I would be in the Doubletree Alana. I was very upset to see the negative reviews, but there are no refunds with Priceline. I called the hotel directly to ask for a QUIET non-smoking room (I told them I didn't care about the view, as long as it was quiet). The person I spoke to was somewhat rude, once she heard I had purchased thorugh Priceline, and told me they could make a note of the no smoking request, but couldn't guarantee any other requests. As I hoping to to relax, and celebrate my birthday, this was not how I wanted my trip to start out. I decided to see what happened and deal with it.I arrived around 9PM in the 40-day downpour that covered Hawaii. I checked into my room, which was clean, a good size and had a lanai, and faced the city/mountain view. The distance from the street was adequate, and traffic noise was not an issue as long as the lanai door was closed. I went to eat in the hotel restaraunt, wich was very small, with a very limited menu. I ended up ordering a small salad, which cost $13. It was not good. I asked how late the hotel bar was open. 10Pm closing. I returned to my room. However, it soon became evident that there were "Spring-Breakers" in the rooms around mine (room 406), as they darted in and out of rooms, made lots of noise, and were obviously having parties going on simultaniously. After an 11 hour flight, I needed my sleep. I went to the front desk to complain. To my surpirse, they immedialtely moved me up to the 16th floor, room 1602.This had the same view, but was at the end of the building. The room was clean and quiet, and I was quite satisfied. I stayed a total of 4 nights, one more than I had originally planned, due to the rain. My final night, booked with the front desk, cost $159.In review, I have to say that the Alana exceeded my expectations, and I had a pleasant stay. The bad raps listed here are not justified, based on my experience. The room was clean and well kept. The free WiFi access in the lobby was very useful, and I eventually made use of the in-room wired connection, which was $10 per 24 hours. The staff were friendly and accomodating.

hotel_name: DoubleTree by Hilton Alana - Waikiki Beach
review_body: We stayed there for 5 nights. The room was musty smelling and had mold growing by the thermastat. View was not great. Convenient location. About 20 minute walk to market and 10 minutes to Hilton's beach area which you can rent chairs and umbrellas and has several stores. Taxi cab to here from airport was about $30--they don't offer shuttle service to and from airport.

hotel_name: DoubleTree by Hilton Alana - Waikiki Beach
review_body: We stayed four nights during the last week of January 2006. We were mostly impressed with the individual staffers, but the managers we encountered seemed in over their heads.The location is OK, but not great. It's a 10-minute walk to the Hilton stretch of Waikiki Beach. If a view is important to you, don't stay here. Our room looked directly into a condo tower that was located across the alley from the Alana.The room was clean and of a decent size. The bathroom was small. The furnishings seemed fresh, but they were starting to show a bit of wear.Because of the very limited climate controls, it was necessary to sleep with our sliding door open. If you can sleep with traffic noise in the background (and the occasional siren, car alarm, backing-up garbage truck, etc.), you'll be OK. It was loud even though we were on the 17th floor. If you need a quiet environment, go somewhere else.Self-parking is not an option. Valet parking was $14 per day with in-and-out priveleges.As Hilton HHonors Gold VIPs, we were not offered an upgraded room, which was very disappointing. We did receive continental breakfast vouchers. Continental breakfast was mediocre, consisting of bread, bagels, small pastries, cold cereal, cottage cheese, hard-boiled eggs and fruit. Without a voucher, the continental breakfast price was $11.95, which we thought was an outrageous price for what was offered.There are two computers with a connected printer available in the business center for those who don't bring laptops. The charge was 20 cents per minute with a $3 minimum. I used it once, but gave up in frustration as a manager and his assistant discussed video surveillance options with a contractor. They were clamoring about where to place the cameras. This is a small room, and it was very uncomfortable. Accomodating guests, you think, would be a priority -- seems like this same exercise could have taken place when no guests were in the business center. And think about it, if the Alana requires video surveillance in this room, which is located directly off the front desk and requires a hotel key to gain access, you might think twice about staying here.We walked by many hotels on Oahu we wished we would have given a chance instead of the Doubletree Alana. Look around -- you can definitely do better than this property.

hotel_name: DoubleTree by Hilton Alana - Waikiki Beach
review_body: What a boring stay. feeble tiny pool. questionable food service. Very clean. I don't intend to stay here again

hotel_name: DoubleTree by Hilton Alana - Waikiki Beach
review_body: the staff is friendly, service is good, and the rooms are very clean. i've stayed here twice, pick the mountain view over the partial ocean as partial means miniscule.the bathroom is on the small side and the japanese-style tub takes some getting used to because of the high edge. i got used to it, but my friends didn't like it. breakfast at padiovani's (onsite restaurant) is limited to sausage, eggs and bacon, or a croisant and fruit.my one complaint is the lack of self-parking. you're forced to valet park, and if you do a lot of in and out parking, it adds up quickly.overall, i'd stay here again.

hotel_name: DoubleTree by Hilton Alana - Waikiki Beach
review_body: This is my last resort when staying in Waikiki. The price is reasonable and rooms are usually available, but the quality is way below Doubletree standards. Be careful if you book a room here. I found that they will charge you for any day that you reserve, but do not stay; not just the first day, but any day.

hotel_name: DoubleTree by Hilton Alana - Waikiki Beach
review_body: We stayed at the Doubletree Alana for 6 nights before Christmas in Dec. 05. We liked the hotel because it was clean, and had a decent location. We liked the fact that it was near the Hilton which has a nice beach, and the Hilton Hawaiin Village is a fun place to walk around. We also like the pool which other reviewers have complained about. It is not a big pool, but it was heated and warm which is what is important to us. We checked the Hilton pool, and several other more expensive hotels, and all of their pools were "freezing" cold.What we didn't like: check-in. We reserved a room with 2 queen beds, but were told at check-in that they only had rooms with 1 king bed. After about 15 minutes of negotiating, they finally found a room with 2 queen beds on a lower level. We also didn't like the fact that the bathroom did not have a fan, and the air in the room became quite humid after morning showers. We finally learned to leave the balcony door open whenever possible to air the room out.

hotel_name: DoubleTree by Hilton Alana - Waikiki Beach
review_body: I stayed here for 3 out of the 4 days I paid for but after seeing nothing but back streets and a mediocre bath/toilet set up and a non existant moutain view even from the 17th floor I checked out and moved to the Hawaii Prince where I paid $5 more for an absolutely fantastic upgrade and the standard of the HOTEL was light years Greater than the Poor relative of the Hilton Chain,.  When I get back to Hawai'i next year the Hawai'iPrince will be the only place I will be staying at. The Marriott/Airport/alana will be forgotten!!.

hotel_name: DoubleTree by Hilton Alana - Waikiki Beach
review_body: The biggest thing was that the hotel is ran on a chiller system. This means you are not able to control the air in your room. I would have prefered an airconditioner that I controlled. The room was clean and the staff were great. The location was fine since the ocean was just around the corner. I am into bargains and the coffe house on the corner offered great food at very reasonalble prices.The hotel is great for families. I would stay here again if the occasion presented itself.

hotel_name: DoubleTree by Hilton Alana - Waikiki Beach
review_body: This hotel is not the worst but not the greatest either. I had to say here for one night because my room at the Hilton Hawaiian Vacation was not ready. I do not recommend this hotel because it is poorly staffed and in a horrible location (very little ocean views). I had a ocean view and I could only see a small glimpse of the ocean. I believe that the only way go get a good room in this hotel is to get the top floor. The rooms are clean and the only saving grace is it location to Hale Koa and Hilton Hawaiian Villiage.

hotel_name: DoubleTree by Hilton Alana - Waikiki Beach
review_body: I recently stayed 6 nights at the Alana for a conference. This was the official meeting hotel so I didn't have a choice in accomodations. Nonetheless, prior to traveling to HI I of course checked out the comments on Trip Advisor but came away confused as to what to expect. Previous comments really ran the gamut, and as it turned out weren't always accurate, so I thought I'd try and set the record straight here (at least as of August 2005).Location: the hotel has both pros and cons regarding its location. It is less than 1 block away from the sprawling Hilton Hawaiian Village, and a 10-15 minute walk into the heart of Waikiki. (Note that some previous posters mention that you have free use of Hilton facilities, including their pool, but I was told by the Hilton staff that this was not true.) The Doubletree also borders Fort De Russy park which is a nice urban green space. A number of chain restaurants (Planet Hollywood, Hard Rock Cafe, Red Lobster, etc.) are close by, as well as some local places. Also there are several rental car offices close by, for those who want to get out of Honolulu for a day. Unfortunately, because the hotel is relatively small and set well off the beach, there are no views of the ocean from the lanais. Oh, I suppose if you are on the top floor in the correct corner of the hotel, you might be able to see some water. But if you plan to stay here, plan on seeing nothing except urbanization in all directions. The hotel is bordered by Ala Moana Boulevard which can be busy (and noisy) at all hours.Rooms: clean and generally well-kept. You have free use of a small fridge and an in-room safe. However, the rooms are small, especially the bathrooms. Be prepared for a weird half-tub shower thing that's a bit awkward to get in and out of because of the tall sides. Decent selection of TV channels. Wireless Internet throughout the hotel for $10/day or $50/week. As mentioned there are lanais big enough for 2 chairs and a small table, but see above regarding the views.Amenities: here the Doubletree suffers. The pool is really, really small, and the whole pool area is composed of just a few lounges and chairs on a concrete patio with no real view. No hot tub. The "fitness center" is actually a couple of treadmills located outside right next to the pool, and I mean about 5 feet from all the kids splashing around. There is a business center, though I didn't use it, and an ATM in the lobby. Service: the hotel staff is friendly and quick to please. The restaurant staff is, however, atrociously slow. Many of my colleagues tried to eat breakfast on the 1st day of our meeting and ended up waiting over an hour for their food. I myself ate there twice, once for breakfast and once for dinner (in the upstairs wine bar), and both times waited 45 minutes after placing my order for the food to arrive - and this was at very non-busy times. Apparently this is a top-notch restaurant in terms of quality, and I admit the food was very good, but the lack of prompt service essentially makes it a non-option for anyone wanting to eat in a timely fashion. Try the Wailana coffee shop a few doors down for tasty, cheap, and quick comfort food instead.Summary: the Doubletree is okay if you don't care about views from the rooms and you don't care about the pool, and if you just want something clean and basic that's convenient to everything else.

hotel_name: DoubleTree by Hilton Alana - Waikiki Beach
review_body: We have recently returned from a week's stay at the Alana. The staff was very friendly and helpful, the rooms were clean, well kept and quiet. The beds and pillows particularly comfortable and the balconies an added bonus for enjoying a late night drink or early morning coffee. Although the hotel is several blocks from the beach, it is easily accessible throught the Hilton. We preferred the quiet and less crowded swimming pool at the Alana over the noisy pools at the bigger hotels, though. We would definitely stay at the Alana again. Hint....for excellent, inexpensive Vietnamese food (not licensed but you can bring your own wine or beer), go to the small family run restaurant around the corner-near the 7-11 and the laundromat. Approximately $10 p/p, including tip, excluding the wine or beer! It is not at all fancy but it is good and the owner/cook will prepare the dishes any way you want. They alsoi do take out.

hotel_name: DoubleTree by Hilton Alana - Waikiki Beach
review_body: We have stayed at the DoubleTree Alana seven or more times over the years.....we are booked again for the end of November........We keep coming back for many reasons:....Reasonable price!....Nice, clean rooms with balconies for two chairs...either a mountain or water view. Rooms include a complimentary safe & ice machines are just nearby on most floors.....Very convenient location....a short walk to the Hilton Hawaiian beach (the widest in Waikiki) or Ala Moana Shopping Centre...Here's a tip to get to Ala Moana SC....continue walking along Kalakaua Ave & cross over the Ala Wai Canal....then walk thru the park at the other side of the canal to Ala Moana Blvd....the mall will be nearby on your right.....Complimentary Honolulu Advertiser (Mon-Sat) for each room+ a small "library" on the 2nd floor near the pool with lot's of magazines & newspapers ...NY & LA Times..SFO Chronicle etc......Big heated pool with both opportunities for sun & shade....kinda private......Free cookies when you check in......Friendly staff......Classy premises with many artworks......It's gotta be good....Airline flight crews stay there!

hotel_name: DoubleTree by Hilton Alana - Waikiki Beach
review_body: I spent 2.5 hours at this hotel in Nov 2004. After this experience I went from spending 75 nights a year at Hilton to 100 nights a year with Marriott.The room reminded me of a college dorm with 1/2 broken furnishings.When I asked the front desk if they had a band aid to treat a blister on my 4 year old foot, the response was “NO”. When asked the same individual a second time the response was NO. When I him a third time his response was, “I will have to fill out paper work if I give you a band aid.”This is when I checked out.
